headline: What Uber’s Spies Really Did
text: The men who gathered intelligence for Uber were supposed to be ghosts. For years, they were un-Googleable sentries, quietly informing executives about the actions of competitors, opponents and disgruntled employees. But the secrecy of the tightknit team ended abruptly in 2017 when one of its members turned on the others, accusing them of stealing trade secrets, wiretapping and destroying evidence.

headline: As U.K. Beckons Truck Drivers, Many in Poland Say ‘No Thanks’
text: In the weeks since the British government announced that it would offer 5,000 temporary visas to truck drivers from continental Europe, part of a campaign to reduce supply chain pressure in the run-up to Christmas, Lukasz Skopinski, a Polish trucker now working in the United Kingdom, has offered this advice to friends back home:

headline: Local News Outlets Could Reap $1.7 Billion in Build Back Better Aid
text: For The Storm Lake Times, a family-run paper in northwestern Iowa, it could mean $200,000 in federal subsidies the first year and nearly $500,000 over the four years after that.

headline: What’s at Stake in the Honduran Presidential Election?
text: Haz clic aquí para leer la cobertura en español de las elecciones en Honduras. Click here to read in English our coverage of the elections in Honduras.

headline: This Fire-Loving Fungus Eats Charcoal, if It Must
text: When a wildfire plows through a forest, life underground changes, too. Death comes for many microorganisms. But, like trees, some microbes are adapted to fire.

headline: ‘You’re Not Helpless’: For London Women, Learning to Fight Builds Confidence
text: LONDON — The thwack of fists hitting hand pads echoed through the studio as pairs of women circled each other, striking blows and blocking them, with a singular focus. A solid jab from one woman elicited an approving murmur from her sweaty partner. Another ducked in anticipation of an incoming left hook.

headline: Years of Delays, Billions in Overruns: The Dismal History of Big Infrastructure
text: As Honolulu sprawled into new suburbs west of Pearl Harbor over the last two decades, city planners proposed an ambitious rail transit line that would sweep riders 20 miles into downtown. The $4 billion estimate in 2006 was hardly cheap, amounting to $200 million per mile.

headline: Omicron, Iran, Stephen Sondheim: Your Weekend Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: For Ku Stevens, Running Is a ‘Profound Act’
text: Watching Ku Stevens fly along the cross-country course in Nevada was like watching a movie play out.

headline: The Week in Business: Choosing the Same Path
text: On Monday, President Biden announced that he was renominating Jerome H. Powell for another four-year term as chair of the Federal Reserve, resisting pressure from progressive Democrats who wanted a change at the top of the Fed and instead choosing policy continuity. But in a move that could appease some of those progressives, Mr. Biden said he would nominate Lael Brainard as vice chair. The role could give her the power to influence everything from the cost of money to the future of digital cash. Mr. Powell, who is expected to receive bipartisan support for his Senate confirmation, will face the task of dismantling the extraordinary efforts the Fed took last year to keep the economy going during the depths of the pandemic. Now, the Fed will need to determine how to start raising interest rates, which have been just above zero since March 2020, without sending the economy into a recession.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 29, 2021
text: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: A soccer game in Portugal is abandoned after Covid reduces one team to 9 players.
text: A top-flight soccer game in Portugal produced instead farcical drama on Saturday evening, after one of the teams was forced to field only nine players, including two goalkeepers, because the rest of its squad had been depleted by a Covid-19 outbreak.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
text: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Scotland announces 6 cases of Omicron, and Britain considers widening its booster program.
text: Scotland reported six cases of the new Omicron variant on Monday, and contact tracing is underway, said Humza Yousaf, the Scottish health secretary.

headline: A Wine Rack on Rails? U.K. Businesses Seek Solutions to Shortages.
text: TILBURY, England — It is called the “wine train,” and every weekend it rumbles out of the port of Tilbury, east of London, on a 100-mile journey to a depot in central England. It looks pretty much like any other freight train, but it carries an unusual cargo: Almost 650,000 bottles of wine.

headline: Iron Bowl Thriller Behind It, Alabama Prepares for No. 1 Georgia
text: AUBURN, Ala. — When it ended, the University of Alabama football players galloped across the field, gesturing mockingly at the stunned Auburn fans at Jordan-Hare Stadium.

headline: When Is a Horror Movie Not a Horror Movie?
text: A few days before Halloween, the @NetflixFilm Twitter account put out a call: “What movie isn’t technically a horror movie but feels like a horror movie to you?” Included was a photo of a freaky-eyed Gene Wilder in “Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory.”

headline: First, I Cried. Then, I Rode My Bike.
text: When I was about 5 or 6 years old, my mother set me down on a purple banana-seat bike. She gripped the back of the seat while I found my balance. Then she gave me a push and let me go, calling, “Pedal, pedal, pedal, glide!” as I rode across the lawn.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Good morning. You holding up? The run-up to Thanksgiving, the holiday itself, entertaining people who’ve traveled great distances to stay with you or traveling great distances to stay with others and entertaining them — the whole thing can be exhausting.

headline: Omicron Is Coming. The U.S. Must Act Now.
text: There’s very little we know for sure about Omicron, the coronavirus variant first detected in South Africa that has caused tremors of panic as winter approaches. That’s actually good news. Fast, honest work by South Africa has allowed the world to get on top of this variant even while clinical and epidemiological data is scarce.

headline: You Can Make Any Day the Best Day of the Year
text: On New Year’s Eves when I was in my late 20s, I would ask my friends to reflect on our best days of the year, the times when we had the most fun, felt the most grateful or were happiest.

headline: The Woman on the Bridge
text: KITTERY, Maine — At 7:05 on an April evening five years ago, Ryan Sanford, a patrol officer in the port town of Kittery, got a call about a van driving erratically on Route 1.

headline: Why the Feminist Movement Needs Pro-Life People
text: When I was a freshman in college, a professor asked our class to define the term “feminist.” We fell silent. I attended a broad-minded liberal arts school, so I assumed our professor was a feminist, but the word carried enough ambiguity and ideological baggage that I was uncertain what to say, and I was not sure if I was one. I am from a fairly conservative background, and my impression of feminism at the time was vague and conflicted.

headline: In a Nonbinary Pronoun, France Sees a U.S. Attack on the Republic
text: PARIS — Perhaps France was always going to have a hard time with nonbinary pronouns. Its language is intensely gender-specific and fiercely protected by august authorities. Still, the furor provoked by a prominent dictionary’s inclusion of the pronoun “iel” has been remarkably virulent.

headline: Kiki and Herb Will Be Back Where They Belong for Christmas
text: Kiki and Herb, the glamorous and harrowing cabaret duo created by Justin Vivian Bond and Kenny Mellman, never performed as reliably as the Radio City Rockettes. But for a while in the early 2000s, no Christmas felt complete without them — especially if you are the kind of person who prefers a belt of Canadian Club to eggnog.

headline: ‘Long Live “Wokeness”!’ Or Is It Doomed?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sylvia Weinstock, the ‘da Vinci of Wedding Cakes,’ Dies at 91
text: Sylvia Weinstock, who took the art of baking to new heights with her 10-foot-tall wedding cakes and their garlands of hundreds, and sometimes thousands, of hand-painted sugar flowers,  died on Nov. 22 at her home in Manhattan. She was 91.

headline: The Netherlands finds at least 13 Omicron cases and expects more.
text: At least 13 people who arrived in the Netherlands on two flights from South Africa on Friday were infected with the Omicron variant of the coronavirus, and more cases will most likely be found, Dutch health officials said on Sunday.

headline: Donors Worry About Fate of Artifacts as Museum on Irish Famine Closes
text: In the mid-1990s John L. Lahey, the president of Quinnipiac College, read a book about the 19th-century potato famine in Ireland and decided that its causes and consequences, its death toll and resulting diaspora, warranted broader exposure.

headline: South Africa, where Omicron was detected, is an outlier on the least vaccinated continent.
text: On the face of it, the emergence of the Omicron variant is the unhappy fulfillment of expert predictions that the failure to prioritize vaccinations for African countries would allow the coronavirus to continue to circulate and mutate there, imperiling the world’s ability to move beyond the pandemic.

headline: 20 Stephen Sondheim Songs to Listen to Right Now
text: The career of Stephen Sondheim, the celebrated Broadway songwriter who died on Friday at the age of 91, spanned decades and included 20 major productions, including forays into television and film. Here is one song from each of those 20 in chronological order, highlighting a genius that was evident from a jarringly early age (even if critics took a while to catch on) for mixing longing and ambivalence into clever, spiky, dependably unexpected lyrics.

headline: Jennifer Nettles Had Sung ‘She Used to Be Mine.’ But Not While Crying.
text: Sara Bareilles and Jennifer Nettles have been friends for over a decade, and Nettles had long been itching to step into Bareilles’s musical “Waitress.”

headline: Virgil Abloh, Path-Blazing Designer, Is Dead at 41
text: Virgil Abloh, the barrier-breaking Black designer whose ascent to the heights of the traditional luxury industry changed what was possible in fashion, died on Sunday in Chicago after a two-year battle with cardiac angiosarcoma, a rare cancer. He was 41.

headline: Los hondureños buscan un alivio de la desesperación en unas elecciones con repercusiones para EE. UU.
text: Tegucigalpa, HONDURAS — Los hondureños votaron hoy en unas elecciones generales tensas, cuyas repercusiones podrían ir mucho más allá del país centroamericano.

headline: Hondurans seek a break from graft and despair in an election with repercussions for the United States.
text: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras — Hondurans voted Sunday in tense general elections that are likely to have repercussions far beyond the Central American country.

headline: Japan bans all foreign travelers, and Australia delays its reopening.
text: Japan on Monday joined Israel and Morocco in barring all foreign travelers, and Australia delayed reopening its borders for two weeks, as more countries sealed themselves off in response to the new Omicron variant of the coronavirus.

headline: Stephen Sondheim, as Great a Composer as He Was a Lyricist
text: “Sweeney Todd” had been open for a few months on Broadway when, one Saturday afternoon in June 1979, I passed by the theater where it was playing. I assumed that Stephen Sondheim’s latest musical was sold out, but I decided to take a chance and see if I could get a ticket to the matinee.

headline: Phil Saviano, Survivor of Clergy Sex Abuse, Dies at 69
text: Phil Saviano carried a terrible secret for much of his life — that in the early 1960s, when he was 11, he was sexually molested by his parish priest in Massachusetts.

headline: ‘Encanto’ Reaches No. 1, but Moviegoers Are Tough to Lure Back
text: Hollywood has stopped running from the pandemic: For the first time since March 2020, movie theaters had a wide array of new films for exclusive screening over the holiday weekend. And studios did not hedge their bets by offering simultaneous streaming options. To see the gloriously reviewed “Encanto,” the campy crime drama “House of Gucci” or the latest installment in the “Resident Evil” science-fiction action franchise, you had to leave the sofa, just like in the old days.

headline: Governors urge caution in the United States on the Omicron variant.
text: Governors across the United States tried to reassure Americans on Sunday that their administrations were closely monitoring the impact of a new coronavirus variant that has alarmed scientists.

headline: Biden will give an update on Omicron Monday as U.S. health officials urge vaccinations.
text: President Biden will give an update on the U.S. response to the Omicron variant on Monday, the White House said in a statement on Sunday evening, as top federal health officials urged unvaccinated Americans on get their shots and eligible adults to seek out boosters.

headline: Preliminary results are expected by 8 p.m. local time.
text: Voting began at 7 a.m. and officially ended at 5 p.m., although the electoral council has urged polls to remain open if there are still people waiting to cast their ballot.

headline: Man Survives Flight From Guatemala to Miami in Plane’s Landing Gear
text: A 26-year-old man survived a flight from Guatemala to Miami on Saturday after hiding in the airplane’s landing gear compartment, officials said.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
text: The new coronavirus variant, first discovered in southern Africa, is showing up across the world.

headline: Swiss voters approve their government’s Covid policy in a referendum.
text: A majority of Swiss voters backed the government’s Covid-19 response policy in a referendum held on Sunday, following weeks of vitriolic public debate and protests.

headline: As China Speeds Up Nuclear Arms Race, the U.S. Wants to Talk
text: The United States has no nuclear hotline to Beijing. The two countries have never had an in-depth, serious conversation about American missile defenses in the Pacific, or China’s experiments to blind U.S. satellites in time of conflict.

headline: Esper Claims Defense Dept. Is Improperly Blocking Parts of His Memoir
text: Former Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper on Sunday sued the agency he once led, accusing officials at the Pentagon of improperly blocking significant portions of an upcoming memoir about his tumultuous tenure under President Donald J. Trump.

headline: A Former Wright Brothers Bicycle Shop Faces Demolition
text: In 1892, the brick building at 1005 West Third Street had several large windows that allowed the residents of Dayton, Ohio, to peek inside and see the Wright brothers, who were still years from becoming pioneers of flight, run their bicycle shop.

headline: Airlines were seeing a travel rebound before Omicron arrived.
text: For months, airline travel has been steadily rebounding, and Sunday was the busiest travel day at U.S. airports since February 2020. But the discovery of the Omicron coronavirus variant threatens to derail the industry’s recovery, as the Delta variant did this summer.

headline: Fetal Viability, Long an Abortion Dividing Line, Faces a Supreme Court Test
text: WASHINGTON — In 1973, in Roe v. Wade, the Supreme Court drew a line. The Constitution, it said, did not allow states to ban abortions before the fetus could survive outside the womb.

headline: As U.S. Hunts for Chinese Spies, University Scientists Warn of Backlash
text: The F.B.I. agents spent nearly two years tailing the professor, following him to work, to the grocery store, and even keeping his college-age son under surveillance. They told the university where he held a tenured position that he was a Chinese operative, prompting the school to cooperate with their investigation and later fire him.

headline: Modern Love?
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — Welcome back to the Monday crossword! I hope you all had a restful and pie-filled holiday weekend that prepared you for a bit of exercise in today's puzzle.

headline: Will the Vaccines Stop Omicron? Scientists Are Racing to Find Out.
text: As nations severed air links from southern Africa amid fears of another global surge of the coronavirus, scientists scrambled on Sunday to gather data on the new Omicron variant, its capabilities and — perhaps most important — how effectively the current vaccines will protect against it.

headline: The Giants and Jets Both Won, but Which Team Was More Enjoyable?

headline: Mikaela Shiffrin Has a World Cup Record, and, Finally, a Rival
text: KILLINGTON, Vt. — The most enduring athletic careers are typically defined by a rivalry with an opponent of comparable talent or skill. Think Magic Johnson and Larry Bird, Tom Brady and Peyton Manning, Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert.

headline: The Patriots’ Dynasty May Not Be Over After All
text: Our NFL playoffs calculator has an up-to-date look at the latest playoff picture.

headline: Carrie P. Meek, U.S. Lawmaker Who Made Racial History, Dies at 95
text: Carrie P. Meek, who was spurred by memories of childhood discrimination and inspired by her heritage as she rose to political power in her native Florida and later in Washington, died on Sunday at her home in Miami. She was 95.

text: Our NFL playoffs calculator has an up-to-date look at the latest playoff picture.

headline: Snowstorm Leaves Dozens Stranded for Days in a Remote U.K. Pub
text: Up on a hill in Yorkshire, England, a crowd filled a pub on Friday to listen to an Oasis tribute band. Inside the pub, the Tan Hill Inn, the beers were cold, the fires were warming and the musicians were electric.

headline: Both parties claim victory as Honduras awaits election results.
text: Hondurans cast their vote Sunday in a largely peaceful, orderly election, that was nonetheless marred by deep polarization, technological shortcomings and fears of fraud.

headline: Los hondureños votaron en paz y ahora esperan resultados con temores de fraude
text: Los hondureños emitieron sus votos en una jornada que transcurrió en su mayoría en paz y en orden a pesar de la polarización, algunos fallos tecnológicos y temores de fraude.

headline: The Packers Use Familiar Hands to Best the New-Look Rams
text: GREEN BAY, Wis. — At the start of November, the Los Angeles Rams were 7-1 and in the hunt for a bye in the first round of the playoffs. The team’s general manager, Les Snead, built on that momentum by trading for the star linebacker Von Miller and signing wide receiver Odell Beckham Jr. after his release from the Cleveland Browns.

headline: Millennials Confront High Inflation for the First Time
text: Americans born after 1980 have been wrestling with sharp price increases for the first time since they’ve been old enough to notice.

headline: Inside the ‘Misinformation’ Wars
text: On Friday afternoons this fall, top American news executives have dialed into a series of off-the-record Zoom meetings led by Harvard academics whose goal is to “help newsroom leaders fight misinformation and media manipulation.”

headline: A woman is charged with arson in quarantine hotel fire in Australia.
text: A woman sent a quarantine hotel in Queensland, Australia, up in flames by lighting a fire under a bed in her room, according to police, triggering the evacuation of the building’s 163 occupants.

headline: ‘Succession’ Season 3, Episode 7: Citizen Ken
text: The streaming services have been cluttered lately with “anatomy of a failure” documentaries, which detail the downfall of formerly white-hot companies like WeWork and LuLaRoe. In nearly all these docs, there’s a scene like Kendall’s 40th birthday party in this week’s episode of “Succession” — some preposterously lavish and borderline cultish shindig, celebrating a business culture about to collapse under its founding genius.

headline: Matthew McConaughey Says He Will Not Run for Texas Governor
text: The actor and author Matthew McConaughey announced on Sunday that he would not run for governor of Texas for now, after months of weighing whether he would seek the office.

headline: ‘Insecure’ Recap, Season 5, Episode 6: Dreams and Ghosts
text: This week’s episode begins with a fever dream that ends with Issa recreating a viral meme. She is fantasizing about talking to Lawrence and Condola at the hospital. In the clouds of her animated mind, she shoots Elijah toward a trash can after kicking Condola into a laundry pile.

headline: No Corrections: Nov. 29, 2021
text: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Quotation of the Day: At Gyms, London Women Fuel Self-Defense Revival
text: “It really just shows how unfair it is, because it is the responsibility for men to stop being predators. But now it’s ended up being our responsibility to pick up martial arts or whatever to stop these predators.”

headline: Word of the Day: hegemony
Your Monday Briefing
text: The new coronavirus variant named Omicron by the W.H.O. is showing up across the world, prompting stock market tumbles and border closures. It has so far been identified in Britain, Germany, Hong Kong, Italy, the Netherlands and other places, usually in people who had recently returned from southern Africa. Here’s a map of cases.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: Willy Wonka and a ‘West Side Story’ Special
text: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Nov. 29-Dec. 5. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Climate Change Is Driving Some Albatrosses to ‘Divorce,’ Study Finds
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Albatrosses usually mate for life, making them among the most monogamous creatures on the planet. But climate change may be driving more of the birds to “divorce,” a study published last week by New Zealand’s Royal Society says.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
text: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Can New York Really Get to 100% Clean Energy by 2040?
text: Two years ago New York committed to the nation’s most ambitious climate goals to shift away from the fossil fuels heating the planet and create a new, electrified economy that stops adding to climate change by 2050. State agencies and private companies went to work building hundreds of wind and solar farms to power businesses, vehicles and homes.

headline: As Ghislaine Maxwell’s Trial Begins, Epstein’s Shadow Looms Large
text: Follow our live coverage of the Ghislaine Maxwell trial on federal sex trafficking charges.

headline: An Auto Show for the Raddest Cars of the ’80s and ’90s
text: Everything was awesome. The music was fresh, the movies were dope and the hair was big. The cars? Rad, then and now. Maybe especially now.

headline: Jeffrey Epstein’s Companion, Ghislaine Maxwell, Goes on Trial
text: Good morning. We’ll look at the sex-trafficking trial of Ghislaine Maxwell, which begins today. We’ll also update the story on the “Fearless Girl” statue. The statue’s permit from the city expires today.

text: Featured Article: “He Sold Away His People’s Heritage. He’s in the Jungle to Get It Back.” Tom Mashberg

headline: Markets rise as investors reconsider the unknowns of the Omicron variant.
text: Global markets steadied on Monday, with stocks on Wall Street and oil prices gaining, as investors contemplated more carefully the knowns and unknowns of a new Covid-19 variant.

headline: What to Know About Mining in Congo
text: The government of Congo is trying to clean up cobalt mining in the country. Here’s the backstory.

headline: Emily Ratajkowski Isn’t Quite Ready to Quit Profiting Off the Male Gaze
text: Emily Ratajkowski is winning in the Instagram era: She has 28.6 million followers and has spent more than half her life making a living as a model. But even at her level of success, she still wonders: When you make a living off your desirability, is the power of your body ever just yours?
